p.seg: BIENNIAL REPORT OF THE / SECRETARY OF STATE OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA FOR THE TWO YEARS ENDING NOVEMBER 30, 1916 * CHARLES W. POOL, Secretary of State TO THE GOVERNOR «alki~ Priatwg Hum, Holmp.

Office of Secretary of State, Lincoln, Nebraska, December 1, 1916. To Hon. John H. Morehead, Governor of the State of Nebraska: Dear Sir: — I have the honor to present herewith my biennial report as Secretary of State for the biennium ending December 1, 1916, which contains a statement of all fees received 'and disbursements made by this office. This report further contains the amount of money appropriated for the maintenance of the department and the expenditures necessary for its operation, together with the list of corporations which have filed dur - ing the last biennium. In this report will also be found a statement covering the transac - tions of the motor vehicle department. Respectfully submitted, CHARLES W. POOL, Secretary of State.

FACTS AND EVENTS IN NEBRASKA HISTORY THE TERRITORY Territory of Nebraska was organized May 30th, 1854. The Territory was a part of the Louisiana Purchase ceded by France to the United States in 1803. First Territorial Legislature held at Oma - ha, commencing January 15th. 1855, consisting of 13 Councilmen and 26 Representatives and the 12th and last session convened at Omaha, Jan - uary. 19th, 1867. The seat of Government was permanently located at Lancaster, the present site of Lincoln, July 2»th, 1867. The Territory sent 3,157 men to the Union army during the 'Civil War. Lincoln statue and memorial erected on State House grounds — unveiled Sept. 2nd, 1912. THE STATE Nebraska was admitted to the Union as a State, March 1st, 1867, by set of Congress passed February 9th, 1867, and by Proclamation issued by President Andrew Johnson and attested by Hon. William H. Seward, Secretary of State, and dated March 1st of that year. The first State Legislature was held in Lincoln, January 7th, 1869. The ■present Constitution was adopted November 1st, 1875. The extreme length of the State east and west is 412 mile*. Its greatest breadth north and south is 208 miles. Its area is 76,895 square miles, or 49,212.000 acres. Number of votes cast in 1868—15,291. Population in l»00 was 1,066,300 Nebraska's population in 1910, 1,192,214 Gain in last decade, 125,914. Gain percentage, 11.8
